items.title: Replace all fa-angle/fa-chevron icons with equivalent `Icon` components

labels.name: design-system
labels.description: All issues relating to design system in Extension

items.body:
### Description
In an effort to replace all font-awesome icons with the new `Icon` component it would be great to replace all `fa-angle-[direction]`, `fa-chevron-[direction]` and `<IconCaret[direction]` components the `Icon` equivalent

One way to find all the `fa-angle-` icons would be to search "fa-angle-"

![Screenshot 2023-01-26 at 3 29 26 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8112138/214974292-17a9d1dc-0e1d-4a84-8375-c686a34d26cb.png)

Similar with `fa-chevron-`

![Screenshot 2023-01-26 at 3 42 25 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8112138/214975261-a64c6a5e-1d70-4907-90e7-9bbf75062598.png)

Same with `<IconCaret`

![Screenshot 2023-01-26 at 4 17 50 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8112138/214979238-3b69c7c2-25f2-4f56-97ba-66ff6855df24.png)

### Technical Details
- Replace all `fa-angle-up` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_UP} />`
- Replace all `fa-angle-right` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_RIGHT} />`
- Replace all `fa-angle-down` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_DOWN} />`
- Replace all `fa-angle-left` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_LEFT} />`
- Replace all `fa-chevron-right` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_RIGHT} />`
- Replace all `fa-chevron-left` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_LEFT} />`
- Replace all `<IconCaretLeft` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_LEFT} />`
- Replace all `<IconCaretRight` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_RIGHT} />`
- Replace all `<IconCaretUp` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_UP} />`
- Replace all `<IconCaretDown` font awesome icons with `<Icon name={ICON_NAMES.ARROW_DOWN} />`

### Acceptance Criteria 
- All `fa-angle-[direction]` have been replaced with their `Icon` component equivalent
- All `fa-chevron-[direction]` have been replaced with their `Icon` component equivalent
- All `<IconCaret[direction]` have been replaced with their `Icon` component equivalent
- PR includes screenshot of before and after of all instances can do it in the code comments if it makes more sense

### References
- [**Icon component documentation in storybook**](https://metamask.github.io/metamask-storybook/?path=/docs/components-componentlibrary-icon--default-story#icon)

items.title: Add deprecation notice to old icon components

labels.name: design-system
labels.description: All issues relating to design system in Extension

items.body: ### Description In an effort to improve new design system component adoption and to prevent any old icons from continuing to be used we could add a JS doc deprecation notice to the icon components in `ui/components/ui/icon`. We may then be able to add an es-lint rule to highlight deprecated components in the code base in another issue. Deprecation notice to add at the above the component of all icon files: e.g. in `ui/components/ui/icon/approve-icon.component.js` ``` import React from 'react'; import PropTypes from 'prop-types'; /** * @deprecated please use the component in ./ui/components/component-library/icon/icon.js */ const Approve = ({ className, size, color }) => (

items.title: Minor: User Profile Image can have colored background

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Issues that are good candidates for DataHub newcomers to tackle

items.body:
**Describe the bug**

Based on this Slack thread: https://datahubspace.slack.com/archives/CV2UXSE9L/p1674716341745369

When a user uploads a profile image with a transparent background, we will see the underlying default color behind the image. 
This is a minor issue but a great first issue.

items.title: Update the README with more current / relevant examples

labels.name: type::bug
labels.description: describes erroneous operation, use severity::* to classify the type

labels.name: source::partner
labels.description: created by or for an Anaconda, Inc. partner company

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: great for new contributors, code change is envisioned to be trivial/relatively straight-forward

items.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched open requests and couldn't find a duplicate

### What is the idea?

Update the README with more current examples. The ones proposed right now are really out of date (IPython Notebook is Jupyter Notebook for a while, numpy 1.6 is... [12 years old](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/commit/039ceba764704d0b4182cd2ecd6b88242f792804) 😂).

It's not that it's incorrect, but showing such an example these days is not relatable, and we might be losing an opportunity to show what `conda` can really do. One of the comments these days in the socials is "why do I need `conda` if `pip` works just fine", and this specific example helps you do something you can already do with `pip`. Maybe it was a BIG deal to have numpy installed with no issues or compilation steps 10 years ago but these days...

What if it said something like:

```bash
$ conda create -n flashy-ml-project jupyter pytorch
```

Or transcending the Python spheres:

```bash
$ conda create -n python+rust rust python
```

### Why is this needed?

_No response_

### What should happen?

_No response_

### Additional Context

_No response_

items.title: Better message for "Function ... could always be true"
items.body:
Consider this example:
```py
def f(x: int) -> str: pass

if f:
    pass
```
It generates this error:
```
t.py:3: error: Function "Callable[[int], str]" could always be true in boolean context  [truthy-function]
```
Instead, if we have a direct reference to a function definition, we could generate a message like this which would be clearer, especially if the signature is complex:
```
t.py:3: error: Function "f" could always be true in boolean context  [truthy-function]
```
There are at least these different cases to consider:
1. Direct reference to a function using a short name of a function (similar to the above example).
2. Direct reference to a function using a module prefix (e.g. `if mod.func:`).
3. Reference to a method (e.g. `if obj.method:`).
4. Reference to a variable/attribute (`Var` node) with type `Callable[...]` (in this case we could show the name of the variable/attribute or the callable type -- both would be okay).
5. Any other expression that produces a callable value, such as `if func():` where `func` returns a callable. Here the best option is to show the callable type as we do now.

items.title: Fix formatting of errors in issue repository
items.body:
This is an example of a reported Bodhi update failure (from https://github.com/packit/specfile/issues/194):

| dist-git branch | error |
| --------------- | ----- |
| `epel9` | ``` There is a problem with creating a bodhi update:
{"status": "error", "errors": [{"location": "body", "name": "builds", "description": "Cannot find any tags associated with build: python-specfile-0.13.1-1.el9"}, {"location": "body", "name": "builds", "description": "Cannot find release associated with build: python-specfile-0.13.1-1.el9, tags: []"}]} ``` |

---

Tasks:

- [ ] Make sure there are no newlines that would break formatting
- [ ] Extract only error description from the exception

items.title: Hubble: add support for SCTP metrics

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Good starting point for new developers, which requires minimal understanding of Cilium.

labels.name: area/metrics
labels.description: Impacts statistics / metrics gathering, eg via Prometheus.

items.body: PR #20033 added initial support for SCTP with Hubble support (see 11a1f688acd8e81f5b1c8738e27a8e5363924611). However, while the PR added support for SCTP in port distribution metrics, it didn't add support for SCTP metrics. For completeness, we should add support for SCTP metrics a similar way as we provide TCP and UDP metrics.

items.title: Cleanup postgres lineage and usage
items.body:
The postgres/lineage.py file is not following the same approach as the rest of lineage sources ([example](https://github.com/open-metadata/OpenMetadata/blob/main/ingestion/src/metadata/ingestion/source/database/postgres/lineage.py#L49)).

The [process_table_query](https://github.com/open-metadata/OpenMetadata/blob/main/ingestion/src/metadata/ingestion/source/database/postgres/query_parser.py#L137) is not returning the same object that it says it does.

We should try to align as much as possible this logic here taking Snowflake as an example

items.title: Switch goreleaser to use github for changelog
items.body:
### Feature request summary

Since we are using GitHub and features are well-defined as issues and through PRs, we should switch the goreleaser changelog method to use [`github` over `git`](https://github.com/unikraft/kraftkit/blob/staging/.goreleaser-stable.yaml#L4). This will associate PR creators in the release message as well as the title of PR.

See: https://goreleaser.com/customization/changelog/

### Describe alternatives

_No response_

### Related architectures

None

### Related platforms

None

### Additional context

_No response_

items.title: contrib: Set custom DNS resolver for Kind nodes

labels.name: help-wanted
labels.description: Please volunteer for this by adding yourself as an assignee!

labels.name: kind/bug/CI
labels.description: This is a bug in the testing code.

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Good starting point for new developers, which requires minimal understanding of Cilium.

items.body:
We are using our [Kind provisioning script](https://github.com/cilium/cilium/blob/master/contrib/scripts/kind.sh) to create K8s clusters when testing in the CI (e.g., https://github.com/cilium/cilium/blob/master/.github/workflows/conformance-datapath.yaml).

Recently, we discovered that on some kernels a default DNS resolver, which is `dockerd`, is troublesome for the BPF host routing, which we want to test in the CI (https://github.com/cilium/cilium/issues/23283).

This issue is about extending the provisioning script to allow us to set a custom upstream DNS resolver (e.g., `1.1.1.1` or `8.8.8.8`) to Kind nodes.

A few ideas how to do that:
- Pass a custom `/etc/resolv.conf` to kubelet via `--resolv-conf` in the Kind / kubeadm config.
- Override `/etc/resolv.conf` of Kind nodes after creating a cluster (no race condition, as CoreDNS pods won't be started, as a CNI is not ready).
- Patch `kube-system/coredns` ConfigMap.
- Patch Kind to allow users to specify custom DNS entries (i.e., `docker run --dns="1.1.1.1,8.8.8.8"`).

items.title: Report Errors at bottom of output on pulumi up

labels.name: area/cli
labels.description: UX of using the CLI (args, output, logs)

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Start here if you'd like to start contributing to Pulumi

items.body:
## Hello!
<!-- Please leave this section as-is, it's designed to help others in the community know how to interact with our GitHub issues. -->

- Vote on this issue by adding a 👍 reaction
- If you want to implement this feature, comment to let us know (we'll work with you on design, scheduling, etc.)

## Issue details

Would it be possible to have the summary section (or whatever is at the bottom) show some indication that there were errors to look into further up in the output? 

This or some other very blatant reporting of errors would improve my workflow considerably :)

I frequently run `pulumi up` commands in short terminals (ie, the integrated terminal in the bottom pane of VS Code or Jetbrains rider). Because of this, the diagnostics get printed off screen when there is an error. I also regularly start a pulumi up, work on something else, and then come back to see if it completed: often the first thing / only thing I see is the Summary section, which tells me how many things were updated, created, and deleted, but doesn't report errors. 

Other issues that are semi related but not the same: [9231](https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi/issues/9231), [1601](https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi/issues/1601),

items.title: Accessibility: Image Alt Tags
items.body:
Add alt tags explaining all of the images clearly in plain text. 

See https://web.dev/text-alternatives-for-images/

See https://github.com/hginit/hginit.github.io/search?q=img+src for list of images.

items.title: Responsive Design: Top nav bar
items.body: Topbar should be sticky, and responsive for mobile layouts. It should list links top to bottom, instead of left to right.

items.title: Mobile Usability: Text too small to read
items.body:
As reported by Google

> A significant portion of the text on the page is too small relative to the width of the page. This makes the text hard to read on a mobile device. Look at the test screenshot for your device to try to identify the problematic text.

> To fix: Specify a viewport for your web pages and set all your font sizes to scale properly within the viewport, so the text will be visible on a device screen. [Read more about best practices for font size](https://web.dev/font-size/).

As reported by [PageSpeed Insights](https://pagespeed.web.dev/report?url=https%3A%2F%2Fhginit.github.io%2F00.html)

> Font sizes less than 12px are too small to be legible and require mobile visitors to “pinch to zoom” in order to read. Strive to have >60% of page text ≥12px.

items.title: Expose activation working set as a metric
items.body:
Orleans internally tracks which grains have been active within the past 200ms or so.

This is tracked in `ActivationWorkingSet` and the information is consumed by `ActivationCollector` and `IncomingRequestMonitor` to determine which grains to monitor. See the relevant PR: #7127

We should publish this information as a polled .NET Metric so that developers can monitor it. See usages of `Instruments.Meter`.

items.title: Include Office information on Office Group Installations

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Issues suitable for new team members

items.body:
**Background**: 
Developers are unaware of what offices are included in an office group install. The installation notification only includes the ID and the name of the organisation & group name, not the ID or name of the offices included. 

**Request**: 
Include more information (Office ID's and Office Names) on the notification email when an app is installed. 

**Current notification for an office group install:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52408607/214322912-37c5681e-511b-4e1a-a15f-0d52ee839e7d.png)


**Example layout/information to include**: 
Organisation: Reapit Sales
Office Group Name: Reapit Testing Account
Office Group ID: RES-GRTA
Offices in group: Marketplace (BCK) 

**Specification**
- Project: Reapit.Services.Offices
- Add office group filtering mechanism to this service, however we need to be able to skip this logic for certain apps (Marketplace Management being the main example) so we will need to build in a mechanism to do this. This was built into the transactions API recently so the same mechanism could be utilised here (with the same parameter store configuration possibly)

items.title: Lua Editor: Step In inconsistent naming

labels.name: feature/scripting
labels.description: This item is related to the scripting tools.

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Issue ready for a new contributor according to the help wanted guidelines.

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

labels.name: sig/content
labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Content.

labels.name: triage/accepted
labels.description: Indicates an issue or PR is ready to be actively worked on.

labels.name: priority/minor
labels.description: Lowest priority. Work that may be scheduled

items.body:
**Describe the bug**
In Lua Editor, *Step In* action is named inconsistently - *Step In* on a toolbar tooltip and *Step Into* on the Debug dropdown.

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Go to Tools > Lua Editor.
2. In the Lua Editor hover over the *Step In* button on the toolbar.
3. Click Debug and find option with the same icon as button in step 3.

**Expected behavior**
Action is named the same on both ways to access it.

**Actual behavior**
Action is named *Step In* on toolbar and *Step Into* in Debug dropdown.

**Video**

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86952082/214319802-f7c54111-46b5-48d3-b037-082ac0b0c959.mp4

**Found in Branch**
Development (681d577)

**Commit ID from [o3de/o3de](https://github.com/o3de/o3de) Repository**
681d577efaef9cc645bf83e3e574296b3b797636

**Desktop**
 - Device: PC
 - OS: Windows
 - Version 11
 - CPU AMD Ryzen 5 3600
 - GPU NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2060 SUPER
 - Memory 16GB

items.title: vim.lsp.buf.code_action should get diagnostics at cursor, not line

labels.name: complexity:low
labels.description: Low-risk, unlikely to cause distant/indirect damage

milestone.title: backlog
milestone.description: Low priority. Not planned for the current target, may be reassigned.

items.body:
### Describe the bug

Use `typescript-language-server` and  `vim.lsp.buf.code_action` returns wrong code actions 
I think`vim.lsp.buf.code_action` parameter diagnostics should be filtered by col. 
The related code is：
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/buf.lua#L765


### Steps to reproduce

1. add a ts file like  that
```typescript
function a(x/**cursor here**/) {
  console.log(x)
}
export const b = 1
```
2. put the cursor at parameter x
3. execute vim.lsp.buf.code_action
4. the code action list has item ` Remove unused declaration for: 'x'`

### Expected behavior

the code action list has not ` Remove unused declaration for: 'x'`

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.9.0-dev-7ef5e363d-dirty

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no

### Operating system/version

windows wsl2

### Terminal name/version

window terminal 1.15

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

build from repo

items.body:
# Localization - ![国语][TW] Taiwanese (国语) <zh-tw.cfg>

## To Be Done by :octocat: contributor

* Some helpful reading
  * [Readme on localization][lclztn]
  * [Quickstart guide to localization][qs]
  * these should help guide you
  * both are in markdown {text}
  * if you are feeling very helpful, kindly translate these as well. ;P
* GameData (done by contributor)
  * [ ] add Localization\<zh-tw.cfg> 🗃️
* Translation
  * [ ] ![国语][TW] Taiwanese (国语) <zh-tw.cfg>

1. Fork this repo
2. Create a branch name it 'translations' or localizations (suggestions)
3. goto `GameData/.../Localization/`
4. copy <en-us.cfg>
5. rename to <en-us.cfg>
6. open the file and translate everything to the right of `#??? = `
7. change the `en-us` to `en-us`
8. please include an attribution to you in the localization file, something like:
  * `// Translated by: [GitHubUserName](https://github.com/GitHubUserName)`
  * alternatively if you want another name from the KSP forums...
1. when done, PR it and you could reference this issue
2.  After it has been merged by me, you may delete your fork.

have fun and thank you! :octocat: 🎃

## GitHub

* [X] assign
  * [X] zer0Kerbal
  * [X] Repo Localization Project
  * [X] Label: type: localization
  * [X] Label: help-wanted
  * [X] Milestone: Localization - Master

    * [ ] [release.md] 🧾

  * Update Social Media

# Localization - ![Polski][PO] Polish (Polski) <pl.cfg>

## To Be Done by :octocat: contributor

* Some helpful reading
  * [Readme on localization][lclztn]
  * [Quickstart guide to localization][qs]
  * these should help guide you
  * both are in markdown {text}
  * if you are feeling very helpful, kindly translate these as well. ;P
* GameData (done by contributor)
  * [ ] add Localization\<pl.cfg> 🗃️
* Translation
  * [ ] ![Polski][PO] Polish (Polski) <pl.cfg>

1. Fork this repo
2. Create a branch name it 'translations' or localizations (suggestions)
3. goto `GameData/.../Localization/`
4. copy <en-us.cfg>
5. rename to <en-us.cfg>
6. open the file and translate everything to the right of `#??? = `
7. change the `en-us` to `en-us`
8. please include an attribution to you in the localization file, something like:
  * `// Translated by: [GitHubUserName](https://github.com/GitHubUserName)`
  * alternatively if you want another name from the KSP forums...
9. when done, PR it and you could reference this issue
10. After it has been merged by me, you may delete your fork.

have fun and thank you! :octocat: 🎃
